awd_titl_txt: Authentic Scientific Practices in the Classroom: A Model-Based-Inquiry Curriculum for the Introductory Biology Laboratory
awd_abstract_narration:
A key challenge facing undergraduate science education is how best to integrate scientific practice into classrooms. It is not enough for students to know the information that scientists have learned. They should also learn the skills that are needed to conduct scientific inquiries. In particular, traditional laboratory courses are frequently misaligned with the ways of thinking that take place in an authentic research setting. Participation in authentic scientific inquiry has been shown to enhance the undergraduate science experience in several ways, but these opportunities are not available to all students. For students at two-year colleges these opportunities are even less common. Instead many students, particularly at the introductory level, are presented with an incomplete or even skewed view of the nature of science - often focused on memorization of facts and completion of procedures rather than the practices that scientists use to develop and refine new knowledge. By contrast, a pedagogical method termed 'Model-Based-Inquiry" (MBI) has been successfully used to engage students in authentic scientific practices. The effectiveness of MBI has been demonstrated in K-12 classrooms and in undergraduate physics and chemistry classrooms, but not in undergraduate biology classrooms. The primary goal of this project is to develop and test a Model-Based-Inquiry curriculum for an introductory biology laboratory course. 

This project will take place as a collaboration between a large, public, research university, the University of Arizona (UA), and a two-year college, Pima Community College. Students will engage in laboratory activities that directly relate to ongoing research at UA. Project impacts will  include: 1) reform of a key introductory course at two institutions which serve large numbers of students from underrepresented groups; 2) national dissemination of a novel curriculum that addresses current needs in biology education; 3) training of postdoctoral, graduate and undergraduate researchers in biology education, including members of groups underrepresented in science; 4) synergistic collaboration between biologists at a two-year college and a research university. In addition to development and implementation of a novel curriculum, the project will include educational research to uncover new information about undergraduate model-based-reasoning through detailed assessment of classroom learning. Project assessment will determine how well the MBI curriculum contributes to students': 1) agency and identity as a scientists, 2) understanding of the nature of scientific inquiry, and 3) cognitive and technical skills for science. Project dissemination will include publication of research results as well as sharing of the curricular approach through distribution of curricular materials and through workshops to engage faculty in MBI-based pedagogy.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this project was to develop and test a laboratory curriculum that would bring the experience of an authentic biological inquiry to undergraduate students. Traditionally, laboratory curricula only allow students to confirm what scientists already know. We developed the AIM-Bio curriculum (Authentic Inquiry through Modeling in Biology) to allow students to build their own explanations for puzzling biological phenomena. We worked with practicing university scientists to bring authentic research organisms and methods to the classroom. In the AIM-Bio curriculum, students are given the opportunity to propose their own scientific models and to test those models through designing and conducting scientific experiments. Importantly, students in the AIM-Bio classroom often develop and test diverse models, as there is not one expected correct answer. This allows students to experience the uncertainty of science and underscores the importance of relying on evidence to draw conclusions.

Through this project, we have demonstrated positive outcomes for AIM-Bio students. AIM-Bio students felt more ownership of their project in the laboratory course and were more likely to identify as a scientist, in comparison to students in the same course who experienced a more traditional curriculum. These outcomes are likely to impact an undergraduate student?s STEM trajectory and may contribute to the likelihood that they will persist in a STEM career. Through the AIM-Bio curriculum, students gain a deeper understanding of the nature of scientific inquiry. We found that the ways they talk about science are different after the course, compared to before the course. We also saw a significant gain for AIM-Bio students on a set of questions designed to measure their scientific skills. Due to the significant positive impacts on students, our department has decided to scale-up the AIM-Bio curriculum to make this experience available to 1,800 student per year. We are also making AIM-Bio instructional materials available to other institutions across the United States.

As a part of this project, significant educational research has uncovered findings that are relevant to understanding ways to support science learning for diverse students. Due to persistent inequalities, diversifying the STEM workforce has been a goal for policy makers for decades. Increasing the rate at which STEM-interested students persist through undergraduate degrees is one tangible way to influence these trends. Our findings suggest that laboratory courses present an avenue to increase the science identity and STEM persistence of large numbers of undergraduate students. Specifically, we found that in a laboratory course students can form a collaborative community focused on scientific goals. Preliminary findings in the AIM-Bio course suggest that participation in this type of community helps students to form a scientific identity. Additionally, as we bring the AIM-Bio curriculum to scale, our institutional context (a large Hispanic Serving institution) will allow us to specifically answer questions about the impact of laboratory curriculum on the STEM persistence of Hispanic students.

Finally, our project not only demonstrated that an inquiry-based laboratory course could positively impact students, but research in the AIM-Bio context has sparked hypotheses about how this type of experience impacts students. Understanding the mechanisms behind student outcomes is essential for helping others to develop effective curricula in other contexts. Through our investigations of student experiences, we have uncovered the importance of designing curricula that are sufficiently complex and open to allow for diverse student ideas to emerge. This affords students agency over their learning process and exposes them to scientific uncertainty, that is a necessary aspect of authentic science. When this type of learning environment is provided to students, many processes naturally emerge that are likely to support scientific learning and positive emotions about science. We found that AIM-Bio students utilized social interactions and reasoning processes, in ways that resemble practicing scientists, to find answers to their own scientific questions. They persisted to overcome challenges in the laboratory and derived personal satisfaction from their accomplishments. Overall, our study points to the natural abilities of introductory students to participate in authentic scientific inquiry, when provided with encouragement, support, and a legitimate responsibility to build explanations from data.
